**Qu’Appelle Progress**

**Public Notice**

The Temperance League of Sintaluta School

A list of parties hereby notified that the Temperance Society has met and resolved that the following matters be brought up for discussion at their next meeting:

1. The temperance movement in the town of Sintaluta School.

2. The temperance movement outside of the school.

3. The temperance movement in the town of Sintaluta School.

4. The temperance movement outside of the school.

5. The temperance movement in the town of Sintaluta School.

6. The temperance movement outside of the school.

7. The temperance movement in the town of Sintaluta School.

8. The temperance movement outside of the school.

9. The temperance movement in the town of Sintaluta School.

10. The temperance movement outside of the school.

Notice is hereby given that all members of the temperance league will meet for a discussion at the town hall on January 1st at 7 PM.

---

**Notices**

**General**

QUEEN’S UNIVERSITY

**Correspondence**

To the Editor:

THE SOUDAN

Correspondence

To the Editor of the Progress:

I am writing this letter to you in order to express my concern about an article that appeared in your newspaper. It seems that there was an error in the report regarding the recent events in Soudan. It is important that we correct any misinformation as soon as possible.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

---

**Correspondence**

To the Editor:

In response to your letter, I would like to provide you with some additional information. The recent events in Soudan have been widely discussed and debated. It is important that we continue to seek accurate and truthful reporting.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

**THE INDIANS**

There are reports and counter-reports being circulated respecting the Indians of the North West. Men who are in a position and qualified to judge say that there is danger of an Indian uprising before spring. There are also reports which contain various points saying there need be no fear. Rev. E. S. W. Bentheath, a gentleman who is a close observer of the Indian affairs and has opportunities of being placed in an impartial opinion as to its value, writes to the Winnipeg Manitoban his convictions on this subject. He may be of the opinion that unless a sufficient force is promptly sent to disarm the Indians we shall see the existing breaches of the laws of the land, not only of its provisions but an uprising against our existence.

**THE FARMERS’ UNION**

A correspondent writes us to the effect that we are a little severe on the Farmers’ Union last week, His Honor the Mayor is doing what he could for them.

The rates do not apply to members of the Union, whose dues are paid on a monthly basis.

**THE CANADA PACIFIC**

There was a report recently issued that it would be necessary to increase the rates on the Canada Pacific from $150 to $175 per ton.

**NOTES AND COMMENTS**

If Mr. Palestine would make a little less noise than he does, he would do more good than harm. It is said that he is not interested in the outcome of any case, but that he is interested in the fact that it has been brought forward.

Mr. Palestine, in his recent article on the Emigration Union and the C. S. B., do you not think there will be a little increase in the number of farmers to whom you write? Is it not true that the Emigration Union has become a national organization?

SAVE THE DATE

May 1st - The annual Alfred Smith Memorial Lecture will be given by Dr. J. M. Mitchelson.

**CONSUMPTION CURE**

An old remedy, tried from practice, and always found to be useful when threatened with consumption. A word of warning, however, about consumption: If any one has the misfortune to fall ill with it, there are remedies available — especially if one can be found who won’t try to take advantage of the situation.

**MARITIME**

Captain Disney, of the I. D., who is in town, says that he has recently visited the Blood reserve, and everything is quiet there. The stolen horses, although not returned, are on the reserve, but they are horses stolen from other Indians, chiefly the Great Cree. As the warriors have not yet appeared, they are not likely to be returned.

**NEWSPAPER**

In conversation with an old timer the other day, he asked him what he thought about the Blood Indians. He replied that he thought they were in mighty bad shape. We asked him what he thought about the situation now? He answered that the situation was not so bad as it had been previously.

**MONTREAL**

They were poor enough in those days, and all joint ownerships must end. If a person took out a mortgage on land for a large sum, and if he defaulted, his creditors could place a lien on all of his property.

**OTTAWA**

We were too late in finding this information. It is certainly important to everyone who owns property in the district.

**SASKATCHEWAN**

Many Indians who are employed in the timber industry are engaged in the harvesting of timber.

OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of ONE DOLLAR, with the object of encouraging advance payment. We can much better afford to publish a paper at that price when we know that every dollar given is paid for, than if we were obliged to collect accounts at a higher figure. Besides we will thus speedily secure a larger circulation, which will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1857.

A FOREST HYMN.

The Thrilling Event Which Inspired This Patriotic Song.

The Star-Spangled Banner.

The thrilling event which inspired this patriotic song was the battle of New Orleans in 1815, which ended the War of 1812. The song was written by Francis Scott Key, who had been detained by the British as a prisoner of war during the siege of Baltimore. He wrote the poem while he was held captive on a British ship, and it was set to music by John Stafford Smith.

The poem describes the American flag still waving over Fort McHenry after a long bombardment by the British fleet. The poem became an instant hit and was later set to music by Smith, becoming the national anthem of the United States.

The poem begins:

O say can you see, by the dawn's early light,
What so proudly we hailed at the twilight's last gleaming?
Whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fight,
O'er the ramparts we watched, were so gallantly streaming?
And the rockets' red glare, the bombs bursting in air,
Gave proof through the night that our flag was still there;
O say does that star-spangled banner yet wave
O'er the land of the free and the home of the brave?

The poem ends with the famous line:

And the people shall be free.

The poem became an instant hit and was later set to music by Smith, becoming the national anthem of the United States.
Rapid City Ripples.

FIRE.

On Sunday morning last about six o'clock the town was aroused by the dread alarm of fire. On exam-
ining it was discovered that Mr. Geo. Newnham's billiard parlor was in flames. The fire was in the Caldwell house adjoining. It was not long before both buildings were reduced to ashes. The damage done was extensive and there was no insurance on the hotel. The billiard room was of late construction and although the fire was bad, it was thought the building would be saved. It was insured for $2000. All the furniture of the building was removed.

On Monday evening the 29th ult., the Freemasons had a very enjoy-
able time at a supper in Bolman's hall, which was highly attended.

At the annual meeting for the non-masonic mayor and council members for the ensuing year held in Bolman's hall on Tuesday, the 29th ult., the following gentlemen were elected to office: Mr. S. A. Head, mayor; Messrs. Webb, Grummit, But-
chart, Hall, McNaught and Ross as councillors.

THE CRADLE.

On the 24th inst., the wife of Thos. Cot-
tingham gave birth to a daughter.

On the 4th inst., the wife of Robert Mac-
donald of a son.

"How to Handle a Queen."

To catch a queen the operator first puts a piece of sugar on the comb near the hive, while a minute later he goes in to fill themselves with honey, which swarms to the comb. The queen soon fol-
lowed the hive. Being filled with honey, she became very active and moved, and will seldom stop unless she is disturbed by some other bee. When the queen is found, the comb containing the wings and out into the cage. Worker bees will not allow her to escape in this manner, it being impossible for them to sting when taken up by the worker. If the workers are sufficient in number, all the queens will be killed, but if the number is increased until sometimes reaching 100, then the worker bees by massing around the cage will prevent the queen from escaping.

GRAND COLONIAL EXHIBITION.

In London, England, 1860.

FOURTY FOUR THOUSAND FEET RESERVED FOR CANADA.

First Royal Exhibition Commis-
sioners, 1860.

THE NATIONAL AND COLONIAL EXHIBITION to be held in LONDON, ENGLAND, commencing May 1st, 1860, is intended to be a great international exhibition, the object of which is to bring into closer relations the nations of Europe with each other.

Besides the great benefits resulting to the arts, a Royal Commission has been appointed to visit the exhibition. The Commissioners will spend ten days there, to inspect another having opened from the same nations.—N. Y. HERALD.

THE GREATEST OFFER YET MADE.

At no former period in the history of the Manitoba Weekly Free Press have the publishers made this offer. We have never before been able to make such an offer, and we believe that the offer is unprecedented in the annals of any newspaper.

In addition to the above offers, we will furnish our subscribers with a handsome set of newspapers, making the price of each paper only 50¢ per week. An arrangement will be made with subscribers to enable them to take advantage of this offer.

WEBSTER'S PRACTICAL DICTIONARY.

To all subscribers to the QUAPPILLE PRESS, who desire it, we will furnish them with a copy of Webster's Practical Dictionary, containing 30,000 words, making the price of each paper only 50¢ per week. An arrangement will be made with subscribers to enable them to take advantage of this offer.

HOW TO SUBSCRIBE.

Enclose Two Dollars in registered letter writing name and postage.

FREE PRESS, WINNIPEG, MAN.
HOME & GOSSIP.

QU'APPELLE

—Sultry, isn't it?
—Zero is getting in his work just now.
—A new school building is on the tips.
—Public school election next Tuesday.
—School matters are attracting little attention just now.
—39 below zero here Wednesday night and 52 below at Edmonton.
—Mr. H. Jagger, of the post of fire and bank, went to Winnipeg yesterday morning.
—Mr. J. B. Russell & Davis, bankers, returned to town yesterday from Prince Albert.
—It is not yet too late to make a New Year's list of your subscrip-
tion to the Progress.
—The public school is expected to open next week with Mr. Wm. Arneil as teacher.
—Mr. S. H. O'Connell's tailoring department will be opened to-mor-
row with every requirement in that line.
—Mr. H. J. Edwards has leased the Town Hall, where he will be found ready to enter the man-
agement of the public.
—The next Judge Richardson will hold court here to be opened at one o'clock. If you have not sued or been sued, the time of your appearance is now.
—Eighty gallons of spirits were seized and spilled by detectives here on Tuesday. It is addressed to E. O. Munday, Co., Prince Albert, and labeled Eucalypt Oil.
—It is the custom with many pa-
pers to miss Christmas and New Year's holidays, but The Progress has not taken advantage of the occasion to establish the custom for itself.
—A number from this place will attend the complimentary dinner to be given at the Fort to Mr. T. W. Jackson and our members in the Northwest County, Wednesday evening next.
—The skating rink is proving in-
to favor as an evening amusement. The ice is always in good condition, and its convenience is appreciated by all who attend. It is open for all, and the central portion is left for the thing for the evolution of the young skaters.
—A public meeting will be held in the Methodist church Friday even-
ing to consider the by-laws and con-
stitution of the Qu'Appelle Church union. There will be a talk on the development of music is invited to attend. Mr. Sutherland, who will take charge, will not only teach the elementary principles, but the higher branches.
—On Wednesday one of those pleasant evenings will also be seen a flutter of excitement, centered at the residence of Mr. G. H. V. Bishop, where the annual meet-
ing of Miss E. Lottin Bulley, daughter of Mr. J. A. Bulley of Diego-
sas, N. B., to be held at the home of Bishop. The ceremony will be performed by Rev. Thos. Lawson. The bride is the recipient of many a hearty present.
—A grand masquerade entwined will be held at the Qu'Appelle skating rink on Saturday evening, the first of what will be novel-
ed. It is expected that there will be a large attendance at various styles of costume, and many prizes. Four prizes will be given—a silver ticket for gymnasium for the best costume, a silver ticket for tickets for ladies for the best female costume, a season ticket for boys for the best costume, and a gold and pair of imperial club skates for the best costume. Prize amount $7.00, only $1.00 to be paid in person, and the tax till nine o'clock, after which all skaters may use the ice. Ad-
mission 25 cents, children 15 cents, and tickets suspended.

WOLSELEY

—The following matters were closed by the Wolseley municipal council of 1886: D. H. Campbell, Robt. Simmons, R. E. Hall, Theo. Fleming, J. D. Martin, Saml. Jolly and James Craig.
—The mill question.
—The way in which the mill ques-
tion was discussed and finally resolved was quite satisfactory—each party for or against an out and unani-
mous mill, or for giving a bonus to the company for the erection of a flour mill here. In sufficient warrant that the wishes of the rate-
payers would be carried out, the com-
pany for all that said from the munici-
pality for this purpose was the less. The company was compelled to go to Indian Head or Fort Qu'Appelle for the purpose of erecting a flour mill here. It will also tend to the realization of full value for their wheat, which they now receive.
—At the meeting held here for the nomination of candidates for the municipal council, the following resolutions were adopted, being moved by Mr. James Fleming seconded by Mr. Matheson:
—Whereas, whereas the want of a flour mill is severely felt by the set-
tlers in this municipality.
—Resolved, That the council have been requested to erect a mill for this municipality, the company agreeing to take up the land required for said mill. Also offers have been made to erect a mill on receipt of so much bonus, also in Debden.
—Be it resolved that this meet-
ing adjourn until Monday next, when it will act as a committee to re-
ceive and consider said offers or any other that may be made, examine the same and report thereon, and if their opinion, such as would be to the advantage of the farmers of this municipality, and the settlement in the form of a petition to the inter-
cayors to request the council to pass the necessary by-laws to secure the erection of a flour mill. The names of the gentlemen all resident in your neighborhood, are respectfully invited.
—Miss L. T. Thomson, Mrs. Hagg, Theo. Fleming, Wm. Howie, Wm. Gibson, Arch. Mclean and A. B. Bumpas.

BALCONIE

—James Robinson, the young man who was arrested with stolen a new overcoat, Mr. Alex. McMillan, of this place, was arrest-
ed at Falls Hotel in the Mounted Police station. He was taken to Regina for trial.
—A pleasing event took place at the residence of Mr. Alexander McMillan at this place on New Year's day. His only daughter, Mrs. J. D. Elliot, was married to Mr. Halpin, of Maclean, Saskatchewan, by Mr. Lawton officiated. Invited guests from Regina and Qu'Appelle were pre-
sent.

FORT QU'APPELLE

—The Council elected for 1886 are Messrs. S. Cuthbert, Theo. Alvin-
son, G. Blakey, W. A. Clark, H. Haynes, J. D. Turner, R. Hooley.
—The council decided that this municipality was rather a hot one in ward three from words they went to show. While not approving of the manner in which Mr. Haynes is almost justified in castigating a man that will say a lone folk is a lone folk.
—It is the intention of Mr. Jackson's friends and supporters to send a petition to the government sup-
porting the claim of Mr. Jackson for the position of Town Hall, now held by Mr. J. D. Turner, for the 13th year. All friends are particularly invited to attend. Dinner will be served at noon and tea at the evening. Tickets, one dollar. Let there be a grand rally of my com-
rades and friends in support of his efforts to procure a good govern-
ment, and an honest and liberal treatment of the matters of the town council and of the Town Hall.

THE ALTAR.

—At Regina, on New Year's day, by Rev. Thomas Lawson, M. A., the marriage of Miss Mary E. Lottin Bulley, daughter of Mr. J. A. Bulley, of Diego-
sas, N. B., to Mr. J. A. Bishop, of Qu'Appelle.
